â€” 5: Understand the business domain

In the environment I used to work as a young engineer, a Business Analyst (BA) was the liaison between the Business and the development team, so I was of the belief that if the BA can explain the requirements to me, I will write the code â€” and that was fine at the early stages of my career. However, I came to the hard realisation that the Business do not care about the code! Our job as Software Engineers is not to produce code, but to add value to the company and make business impact.

Taking time to understand how the business operates is a major, but often neglected, part of our job. There is no easy, one-size-fits-all answer as we all probably specialise in different domains, but an idea is to talk to the Business and ask for advice, attend training courses or even seek for a business certification. Your final aim should be to demonstrate that you can contribute a lot of unique and valuable insights in a discussion with the Business! Try for example to point out specifications that are in error and make alternate suggestions that they accept.
In order to solve a problem, you must first understand the problem
This will help you tremendously if you would like to progress from a Programmer to Dev Lead, Architect, or Project Manager and gain your seat at the table!
â€” 4: Enhance your people skills

The idea that developers are introverted geeks that only work alone is totally outdated. Programmers are part of a team and they interact with their peers, their managers and the business users on a daily basis. The number one competence to improve is humility. You might have read my views on this: Programmers with passable technical aptitude but excellent soft skills are outperforming technical gurus in terms of career advancement!!
This is just one aspect of becoming a better developer; for a rounder approach to people skills I prompt you to read these two outstanding books:

text: â€” 3: Be a DevOps-minded developer

Many programmers think that their main responsibility is to code and they consider DevOps as a fluffy concept that doesnâ€™t actually help them improve things on the ground. That is simply not true and embracing DevOps can dramatically help your programming career. My suggestion is to start with these basic DevOps skills:
Continuous Delivery

Continuous Delivery (CD) is the process of building, testing, configuring and deploying software from a build to a production environment. To deliver value to your end users, you must release continually, rapidly, consistently and without errors. Atlassianâ€™s Bamboo is my tool of choice as it is easy to configure and integrates out of the box with Jira. Here you can find more info. For an open-source equivalent try Jenkins.
If you still rely on manual processes to deploy your software, do yourself a favour and stop! When you are familiarised with the benefits then using CD will be a no-brainer!
Testing Automation

Software testing is no longer solely the responsibility of the Quality Assurance (QA) specialists associated with the project. When you are continuously delivering software, it cannot be possible to rely on ad hoc and manual tests. I assume you have basic knowledge of TDD (Test Driven Development) so I encourage you to get comfortable with several testing techniques and also BDD (Behaviour Driven Development):
Application Monitoring

Reactive software remedies are not ideal as they disrupt the customer service, so every organisation provides a sort of APM (Application Performance Monitor) system that oversees the CPU usage, disk space, SLAs etc. But as a developer what else can you introduce to aid and complement this effort? Monitoring and analysing logs is important to track application performance, troubleshoot, perform root cause analysis, review system behaviour and predict future disruptions.

I recommend you focus on the Elastic (ELK) stack, as the company has put together arguably the most popular log management platform for both open source and commercial usage: Elasticsearch for deep search and data analytics, Logstash for centralised logging, log enrichment and parsing and Kibana for powerful and beautiful data visualisations. Their online videos are a nice entry point.
DevOps have exerted significant impact on software development. We just scratched the surface here, but a great resource with DevOps â€˜goodnessâ€™ to accompany your journey is DZone.
â€” 2: Focus on the user experience

Most backend developers think that UX (user experience) design equals UI (user interface) design, so they assume UX is the responsibility of the front end developers. Nope! I will explain the difference by â€˜â€˜paraphrasingâ€™â€™ a picture I came across in the â€˜Hands-On UX Design for Developersâ€™ book. Here is my take on it:

UX design is not (only) about visuals; it focuses on the overall feel of the user experience and involves the entire software development lifecycle. How often does the software break, how do you give feedback to the user, how intuitive is the interface, how long does it take to run a batch, how short are the response times, what is the time-to-market to resolve an issue [yes that plays a role here too].
I am sharing with you five simple rules on UX that my team and I have learnt the hard way after many years dealing with very hard-to-please bankers and risk managers:

texts: Involve the users when designing software
Performance is as important as functionality
Error messages should be aimed at the users, not the developers
Clear navigation in a self oriented user interface is the best
Quality assurance is an integral part of software development

text: On UI design in particular these are a couple of resources I recommend you check out: The 101 UX Principles book and also the 99% Invisible podcast.
â€” 1: Learn the art of software crafting

It doesnâ€™t take a huge amount of knowledge and skill to get a program working. Everyone can do it. Getting something to work is not a hard thing â€” getting it right is! Imagine the very first program you wrote when you took your first programming class. And compare it to now. See how far you have come?

Let me now introduce you to the magical world of design patterns, solid principles and software architecture paradigms to see how you can position yourself with the elect few that write elegant software that lasts, has high cohesion and loose coupling and most notably is easy to comprehend, extend and maintain.

text: Software engineering would be better served if you keep your mind on architectural plumbing instead of the latest languages, trendy frameworks, or other development fad. I am not saying that these do not matter; in fact the opposite is true! But if you would like to step up your career, this is my first piece of advice: Focus your energy on structuring and then growing software in such a way that the cost of maintenance is low. In other words: learn about software architecture; your employer will love you!
